content:
Jay Gould, The Mismeasure of Man(New York: Norton, 1981), 235.



This page intentionally left blank



Fallacies of Vacuity
Arguments are vacuous when they don’t go anywhere. This happens in two main
ways. Sometimes an argument begins by assuming its conclusion or some inde-
pendent reason for its conclusion, so the argument makes no real progress beyond
its own assumptions. In other cases, the argument’s conclusion is empty, so the ar-
gument has nowhere in particular to go. Both kinds of argu
